description:
Hypoxylon trugodes is a species of fungus that belongs to the genus Hypoxylon, which is a group of ascomycete fungi. Hypoxylon trugodes is a wood-decaying fungus that typically grows on the dead or decaying wood of various hardwood tree species.

The fungus produces small, dark-colored, spherical or disc-shaped fruiting bodies called perithecia, which are embedded in a stroma (a cushion-like structure). The perithecia contain the asci, which are the structures that house the fungal spores called ascospores. The ascospores are the primary means of dispersal and reproduction for this species.

Hypoxylon trugodes is known to play a role in the decomposition of dead woody material, contributing to the nutrient cycling in forest ecosystems. It is commonly found in temperate and subtropical regions around the world, where it can be an important component of the fungal community in forested environments.
